newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria 1997 beet sugar production seen rising.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria 1997 beet sugar production seen rising.

text.p: Bulgaria's production of white sugar from beet is seen rising to 10,000 tonnes this year from 5,100 last year, the Union of Sugar Producers said on Friday.
However, output would be down from the 14,700 tonnes produced in 1995, the Union's chairman, Boris Tersiev, told a news conference.
Domestic sugar consumption stood at 26 kg per capita in 1996, National Statistics Institute figures showed. Annual consumption was forecast to rise to 33 kg per capita by 2001.
Including imports processed in Bulgaria's six sugar plants, total whites production last year amounted to 297,500 tonnes, up from 274,000 in 1995, Tersiev said.
"Bulgaria exported 131,000 tonnes of white sugar to Macedonia, Albania, Greece and Turkey (in 1996), up from 112,000 tonnes in 1995 and 66,000 tonnes in 1994," Tersiev said.
"A further 19,000 tonnes of white sugar were exported in the first quarter of this year," he added.
Bulgaria's cabinet scrapped price controls on sugar last month in line with pledges to the International Monetary Fund to liberalise trade in agricultural goods.

"Sugar producers are not optimistic about the development of this industry in the future because of low local retail price of some $0.40-0.45 per kilo of white sugar and a farm gate price which was set by the cabinet at $20 per tonne of sugar beet," Tersiev said.
"We hope that Bulgaria's integration in the Central European Free Trade Association and in the European Union will boost sugar beet production," he said. -- Sofia Newsroom +359-2 981 4145
